thread.title: Six year after his overthrow, Egypt’s Hosni Mubarak is freed from detention
thread.title_full: Six year after his overthrow, Egypt’s Hosni Mubarak is freed from detention - The Washington Post

author: washingtonpost blogs
title: Six year after his overthrow, Egypt’s Hosni Mubarak is freed from detention
text:
March 24 at 8:39 AM Follow @raghavanWaPo CAIRO — Six years after his overthrow, former Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak was freed from detention on Friday, dashing the hopes of many who saw Mubarak’s downfall as a sign that Arab leaders were no longer immune to corruption and repression.
On Friday morning, Mubarak left the Maadi Military Hospital in Cairo, where he’s been under house arrest since 2013, and traveled to his mansion in the upscale northern suburb of Heliopolis, his lawyer said.
The 88-year-old leader’s release comes weeks after the nation’s top appeals court cleared him of the deaths of hundreds of protesters in the 2011 populist revolts, part of the Arab Spring uprisings, that ended Mubarak’s three-decade- rule.
“Yes, Mubarak has been released today,” Mubarak’s lawyer, Farid el-Deeb, said in a brief telephone interview.
Mubarak was the first leader to face trial after the Arab Spring uprising, arrested two months after he was ousted from office by an 18-day-long revolution that drew hundreds of thousands of Egyptians into the streets of Cairo and other cities.
[ From the archives: With peace, Egyptians overthrow a dictator ]
The following year, Mubarak received a life sentence in prison, along with his interior minister and six aides. But an appeals court later ordered a retrial. In 2014, the court dismissed the charges of killing protesters, citing the prosecution for technical flaws, and the ruling earlier this month further absolved him of any accountability and paved the way for his release.
Mubarak, who became president in 1981 after the assassination of President Anwar Sadat, was initially held in Tora prison before being transferred to the hospital due to his deteriorating medical condition.
On Friday, Deeb said that the former leader’s “health is good,” and that he would continue to receive medical treatment at his home. He added that were no other legal cases pending against Mubarak and that “his legal situation is fine.”
“There is nothing wrong,” said Deeb.
Mubarak, he added, has no plans to hold a news conference or participate in any media appearances. Nor does he have any firm ideas yet on how he plans to spend his time in the weeks and months ahead,
“He has no plans for the near future,” said Deeb. “He is just staying at home and resting.”
